Iniz – KVM in Amsterdam and OpenVZ in New York, Los Angeles and Amsterdam

amsterdam, Iniz.com, kvm, los angeles, netherlands, New York City, openvz, USA June 14, 2014 @ 1:00 pm, by Rashid Alkhaili

Patrick, from INIZ, has sent the community 7 exceptional OpenVZ as well as a KVM offer from Amsterdam. INIZ has been featured many times before, and reviews from users have been quite stellar throughout the life of the company. They have also achieved 3rd place in the Top Provider quarterly poll three times in a row. The nodes that the virtual servers are hosted on are quite beefy, and very generous. They consist of Dual E5-2650 CPUs, HP RAID with flash cache and 10x4TB RAID10 disks in the Netherlands, and Dual E5-2620v1/2 CPUs, LSI 9271 RAID with CV and 8x3TB RAID10 in the United States for both of their locations. A great advantage at INIZ, which we do not see every day with other providers, is the use of dual 1Gbps uplinks for redundancy at the node level. rDNS entries are easily, and instantly configured via SolusVM, eliminating the need to waste countless hours by opening a support ticket for it to be manually configured. All offers include 1 IPv6 address by default, additional IPv6 addresses can be requested by opening a ticket. With these seven offers I am sure that there are plans that satisfy everyone’s needs. If you are a current customer with INIZ, please do share your reviews and comments below.

More mouthwatering offers await you inside, click “More” to see.


Unlike the majority of providers here on LowEndBox, only a few actually run their own BGP session. INIZ is one of the few and proud. They run their BGP (AS62599) sessions at each of their locations with the US, as well as the EU. Not to mention that they are also now a RIPE member, congratulations!

INIZ accepts payments via Paypal, as well as credit cards through their website. Servers are usually delivered instantly after payment. Refunds are only possible within the first 5 days of your first order only, subsequent orders are not eligible for refunds. However, for their other brand “OpenVZ.io” no refunds are offered. A quick reminder of what is not allowed on INIZ’s network is (but not limited to) IRC networks, Mass Mailing, Public torrents/VPN/Proxies, Minecraft and other IO intensive applications, TOR, Phishing, and Mass Brute Forcing. For a full list, please read their Terms Of Service document.

NForce, Amsterdam, NL (EU): http://ams-nl.lg.iniz.com
